prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 NGC 4395 mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the nearby dwarf galaxies NGC 4395, NGC 4178, NGC 3621 and NGC 1042 at band 3 and band 6 in the emission lines of 12CO(1-0) and 12CO(2-1). We are interested in mapping the cold gas in the central ~1-4 kpc region of the IMBH host galaxies with a spatial resolution of ~35-98 pc. For this, we require a rectangular field of 5 pointings spaced at the Nyquist spacing in order to obtain uniform sensitivity across the beam of just one pointing for each galaxy. For the two spectral line windows, we ask for a spectral resolution of 1.271-2.551 km/s. At expected line widths of 40-100 km/s, this is more than enough to fully sample the line profiles.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We center one spectral window on the 12CO(1-0) and one on the 12CO(2-1) line. For the two spectal line windows, we ask for a spectral resolution of 1.271 km/s. At an expected line width of 40 km/s, this is more than enough to fully sample the line profiles.

We are interested in mapping the cold gas in the central ~1 kpc region of the IMBH host galaxies NGC 4395 with a spatial resolution of ~35 pc. We mosaic this region on the sky using a rectangular field of 5 pointings spaced at the Nyquist spacing in order to obtain uniform sensitivity across the primary beam of just one pointing. ACA observations are also requested, as suggested by the OT. The observations proposed in this Science Goal will allow us to resolve structures down to 1.8 arcsecond scale giving 28 spatial resolution elements in a single pointing.

The sensitivity requirement is driven by the 12CO(1-0) and 12CO(2-1) lines. Assuming a peak flux density per synthesized beam for 12CO(1-0) of 10.0 mJy for NGC 4395, we achieve a S/N ~ 5 over a 1.271 km/s bandwidth. This bandwidth corresponds to ~3 percent of the estimated line width of 40.0 km/s. Since we want to accurately model the line profile, we need an S/N of 5 in each of these 1.271 km/s bins. The S/N over 1/3 of the line width will be accordingly higher.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 NGC 4178 mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to observe the nearby dwarf galaxies NGC 4395, NGC 4178, NGC 3621 and NGC 1042 at band 3 and band 6 in the emission lines of 12CO(1-0) and 12CO(2-1). We are interested in mapping the cold gas in the central ~1-4 kpc region of the IMBH host galaxies with a spatial resolution of ~35-98 pc. For this, we require a rectangular field of 5 pointings spaced at the Nyquist spacing in order to obtain uniform sensitivity across the beam of just one pointing for each galaxy. For the two spectral line windows, we ask for a spectral resolution of 1.271-2.551 km/s. At expected line widths of 40-100 km/s, this is more than enough to fully sample the line profiles.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We center one spectral window on the 12CO(1-0) and one on the 12CO(2-1) line. For the two spectal line windows, we ask for a spectral resolution of 2.551 and 1.275 km/s, respectively. At expected line widths of 80-100 km/s, this is more than enough to fully sample the line profiles.

We are interested in mapping the cold gas in the central ~4 kpc region of the IMBH host galaxies NGC 4178, NGC 3621 and NGC 1042 with a spatial resolution of ~98 pc. We mosaic this region on the sky using a rectangular field of 5 pointings spaced at the Nyquist spacing in order to obtain uniform sensitivity across the primary beam of just one pointing. ACA observations are also requested, as suggested by the OT. The observations proposed in this Science Goal will allow us to resolve structures down to 1.2 arcsecond scale giving 42 spatial resolution elements in a single pointing.

The sensitivity requirement is driven by the 12CO(1-0) and 12CO(2-1) lines. Assuming a peak flux density per synthesized beam for 12CO(1-0)of 21.0, 21.0, 18.0 mJy for NGC 4178, NGC 3621, NGC 1042, respectively, we achieve a S/N ~ 5 over a 2.551 km/s bandwidth. This bandwidth corresponds to less than 3 percent of the estimated line width of 100, 100, 90 km/s, respectively. Since we want to accurately model the line profile, we need an S/N of 5 in each of these 2.551 km/s bins. The S/N over 1/3 of the line width will be accordingly higher.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The past decade has seen a significant shift in our understanding of AGN, as evidence for active intermediate mass black holes has become relatively common in the local universe. These objects span a wide range of luminosities, but they are most commonly found at the center of star forming S0 and disk galaxies, and an increasing number are being detected in dwarf galaxies. Low luminosity AGN are believed to be fueled by cold gas accretion, but thus far it has been a challenge to constrain these processes observationally. We plan to map cold gas in four nearby galaxies with well-established low luminosity AGN signatures: NGC 4395, NGC 4178, NGC 1042, and NGC 3621. Using the superb resolution of ALMA, we will determine the spatial and kinematic structure of the molecular gas in the central regions of these galaxies, to study the interplay of cold gas and the central AGN.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astro and Particle Physics, Innsbruck, University of
